required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Promoting Adherence to Improve Effectiveness of Cardiovascular Disease Therapies
clinical_study.official_title: Promoting Adherence to Improve Effectiveness of Cardiovascular Disease Therapies (PATIENT)

collaborator.agency: Kaiser Foundation Hospitals, Center for Health Research
Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this randomized clinical trial is to determine whether two low-intensity, technology based interventions, when compared to each other and to usual care, improve adherence to selected medications that are used to treat people with cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diabetes.

detailed_description.textblock: The frequent failure of patients to adhere to long-term medication regimens remains the single greatest challenge for chronic-disease management. Many studies have linked medication non-adherence to treatment failure; unnecessary and dangerous intensification of therapy; and excess health care costs, hospitalizations, and deaths. Although some interventions have been shown to significantly enhance medication adherence, the strategies used are often complex, labor-intensive, and of variable effectiveness. Simple interventions designed to make small-but-significant improvements in population-based adherence may thus offer a novel, cost-effective, and easily-disseminated alternative to current approaches for enhancing adherence. The proposed PATIENT study will use health information technology (automated phone calls and access to an electronic medical record) to test two such interventions and compare them to each other and to usual care alone.

primary_outcome.description: We used a modification of the Medication Possession Ratio (MPR) as our primary outcome measure. The MPR is computed as the number of days' supply of medication dispensed during a given time window divided by the time between the first dispensing in the window and the end of the window. Our modified MPR (mMPR) also accounted for medication that was on hand at the start of the window and ignored any days' supply that would extend beyond the end of the window. We used medication dispensing data from the Kaiser outpatient pharmacies to calculate a modified medication possession ratio (mMPR) for statins among the subset of randomized participants who were using these drugs. Nominally mMPR provides an estimate of the proportion of days during the follow-up period during which the participant was adherent to their prescribed medications.

primary_outcome.measure: Adherence to Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme Inhibitors (ACEIs) and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs)
primary_outcome.description: We used medication dispensing data from the Kaiser outpatient pharmacies to calculate a modified medication possession ratio (mMPR) for the subset of randomized participants who were using ACEIs or ARBs. Nominally mMPR provides an estimate of the proportion of days during the follow-up period during which the participant was adherent to their prescribed medications.

secondary_outcome.description: Binary indicator of good statin adherence, defined as an mMPR>0.80. 1=yes, 0=no.
Binary indicator of good ACEI/ARB adherence, defined as an mMPR>0.80. 1=yes, 0=no.
Mean of last 5 SBP measurements captured in the electronic medical record for the 12 months post randomization.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage With Good (<140/90 mmHg) Blood Pressure Control
secondary_outcome.description: Using the mean of last 5 available blood pressure measurements post randomization, we defined BP control as a means systolic BP <140 mmHg and a mean diastolic BP < 90 mmHg.

secondary_outcome.measure: Post Intervention Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Level
secondary_outcome.description: We used the latest LDL (fasting or nonfasting) available during 12 months post randomization. no missing data were imputed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage With Good (<=100mg/dL) Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Control
secondary_outcome.description: Using the last LDL measurement (fasting or nonfasting) available in the EMR post randomization, we defined good control as an LDL level <= 100 mg/dL.

arm_group.description: Participants in this arm received their usual care with no restrictions.
automated phone calls & Educational mailings and follow-up for nonadherence

intervention.description: The IVR intervention consisted of automated phone calls designed to educate participants about their medications and to assist them in refilling their prescriptions. The calls fell into two basic types: simple refill reminders and "tardy" calls for those who were overdue for a refill. Calls occured monthly and were triggered by dispensing information in the electronic medical record (EMR). Call features included the ability to transfer individuals to Kaiser's automated prescription refill service as well as to care managers. Although the calls were triggered by and focused on use of ACE inhibitors, ARBs and statins, they also included reminders to use aspirin, which is known to also be effective for secondary prevention in this patient population.

intervention.intervention_name: Educational mailings and follow-up for nonadherence
intervention.description: Participants received bimonthly educational materials by mail. In addition, patients received mailed refill reminder letters and their providers were notified electronically if the patients failed to refill in response to the automated calls. The educational mailings included personalized health information such as the participant's cholesterol and blood pressure readings, as well as tools for improving adherence such as frequently asked questions (FAQs) about their medications, a pocket-sized calendar for tracking refills with pertinent phone numbers and web site information and space for them to write their medical record number and prescription numbers.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Aged 40 years or older as of time of randomization.
- Flagged in KP's databases as having either diabetes or atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease(defined as coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, or a history of atherosclerotic stroke) at the time of randomization
- At least one dispensing of an ACEI, ARB, or statin from a Kaiser Permanente (KP) outpatient pharmacy during the baseline year.
- Suboptimal adherence ((MPR<0.9) to either statins or ACEI/ARBs during the baseline year
- Continuous membership in KP for the 12 months prior to randomization.
- Qualified for an intervention call at the time of randomization.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Evidence in the electronic medical record (EMR) of allergy or intolerance to statins or ACE inhibitors/ARBs
- medical conditions that would contraindicate use of statins or ACEI/ARBs
- Absence of either a phone number or mailing address in the EMR
- for Kaiser Permanente Hawaii, clinics whose patients tend to fill prescriptions primarily at non-KP pharmacies
- on Kaiser Permanente's "do not contact" list or in other research studies that could add undue burden

overall_official.affiliation: Center for Health Research, Kaiser Permanente Northwest

results_reference.citation: Vollmer WM, Owen-Smith AA, Tom JO, Laws R, Ditmer DG, Smith DH, Waterbury AC, Schneider JL, Yonehara CH, Williams A, Vupputuri S, Rand CS. Improving adherence to cardiovascular disease medications with information technology. Am J Manag Care. 2014 Nov;20(11 Spec No. 17):SP502-10.

Smith DH, O'Keeffe-Rosetti M, Owen-Smith AA, Rand C, Tom J, Vupputuri S, Laws R, Waterbury A, Hankerson-Dyson DD, Yonehara C, Williams A, Schneider J, Dickerson JF, Vollmer WM. Improving Adherence to Cardiovascular Therapies: An Economic Evaluation of a Randomized Pragmatic Trial. Value Health. 2016 Mar-Apr;19(2):176-84. doi: 10.1016/j.jval.2015.11.013. Epub 2016 Feb 12.

Owen-Smith AA, Smith DH, Rand CS, Tom JO, Laws R, Waterbury A, Williams A, Vollmer WM. Difference in Effectiveness of Medication Adherence Intervention by Health Literacy Level. Perm J. 2016 summer;20(3):38-44. doi: 10.7812/TPP/15-200. Epub 2016 Jun 29.

patient_data.ipd_description: At the request of AHRQ we did not create a formal public data release.

group.title: Usual Care (UC)
group.description: Participants in this arm had full access to all care they were normally entitled to as part of usual care

group.title: Interactive Voice Recognition (IVR)
group.description: In addition to their usual care, participants in the Interactive Voice Recognition (IVR) arm received automated phone calls, triggered by dispensing events in the electronic medical record (EMR), to educate patients about their medications and assist them in refilling their prescriptions. The calls fell into two basic types: simple refill reminders and "tardy" calls for those who were overdue for a refill. Calls occured monthly and were triggered by dispensing information in the EMR. Call features included the ability to transfer individuals to Kaiser's automated prescription refill service as well as to care managers. Although the calls were triggered by and focused on use of ACE inhibitors, ARBs and statins, they also included reminders to use aspirin, which is known to also be effective for secondary prevention in this patient population.

group.title: Enhanced IVR (IVR+)
group.description: Participants in the IVR+ arm received all components of the IVR intervention and in addition were mailed educational materials bimonthly during the intervention. In addition, both IVR+ participants and their primary care providers received mailed notifications when they did not fill their medications in response to the automated calls. The educational mailings included personalized health information such as the participant's cholesterol and blood pressure readings, as well as tools for improving adherence such as FAQs about their medications, a pocket-sized calendar for tracking refills with pertinent phone numbers and web site information and space for them to write their medical record number and prescription numbers.

participants_list.participants: Separate analyses were done for statin users and ACEI/ARB users. This is the combined N.
Separate analyses were done for statin users and ACEI/ARB users. This is the combined N.
Separate analyses were done for statin users and ACEI/ARB users. This is the combined N.
mean (SD) duration of follow-up was 9.7 (2.3) mos, but we computed an adherence score for everyone.
mean (SD) duration of follow-up was 9.6 (2.4) mos, but we computed an adherence score for everyone.
mean (SD) duration of follow-up was 9.6 (2.5) mos, but we computed an adherence score for everyone.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Adherence to Statins
outcome.description: We used a modification of the Medication Possession Ratio (MPR) as our primary outcome measure. The MPR is computed as the number of days’ supply of medication dispensed during a given time window divided by the time between the first dispensing in the window and the end of the window. Our modified MPR (mMPR) also accounted for medication that was on hand at the start of the window and ignored any days’ supply that would extend beyond the end of the window. We used medication dispensing data from the Kaiser outpatient pharmacies to calculate a modified medication possession ratio (mMPR) for statins among the subset of randomized participants who were using these drugs. Nominally mMPR provides an estimate of the proportion of days during the follow-up period during which the participant was adherent to their prescribed medications.
outcome.population: All randomized participants who were taking statins at the time of randomization

measure.title: Adherence to Statins
measure.description: We used a modification of the Medication Possession Ratio (MPR) as our primary outcome measure. The MPR is computed as the number of days’ supply of medication dispensed during a given time window divided by the time between the first dispensing in the window and the end of the window. Our modified MPR (mMPR) also accounted for medication that was on hand at the start of the window and ignored any days’ supply that would extend beyond the end of the window. We used medication dispensing data from the Kaiser outpatient pharmacies to calculate a modified medication possession ratio (mMPR) for statins among the subset of randomized participants who were using these drugs. Nominally mMPR provides an estimate of the proportion of days during the follow-up period during which the participant was adherent to their prescribed medications.
measure.population: All randomized participants who were taking statins at the time of randomization

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline adherence level groups.
analysis.method_desc: adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications patient is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline statin adherence.
analysis.estimate_desc: Adjusted difference in adherence for IVR group versus UC group, calculated as IVR - UC.

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR+ versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline adherence level groups.
analysis.method_desc: adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications participant is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline statin adherence.

outcome.title: Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP)
outcome.description: Mean of last 5 SBP measurements captured in the electronic medical record for the 12 months post randomization.
outcome.population: The analysis sample was restricted to ACEI/ARB users with at least one post intervention SBP measurement recorded in the EMR. We did not impute any missing data.

measure.title: Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP)
measure.description: Mean of last 5 SBP measurements captured in the electronic medical record for the 12 months post randomization.
measure.population: The analysis sample was restricted to ACEI/ARB users with at least one post intervention SBP measurement recorded in the EMR. We did not impute any missing data.

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline SBP level groups.
analysis.p_value_desc: As noted above, the a priori threshold for statistical significance for this test was .025.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications patient is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline SBP group.

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR+ versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline SBP level groups.
analysis.p_value_desc: As noted above, the a priori threshold for statistical significance for this test was .025.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications participant is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline SBP group.

outcome.title: Percentage With Good (<140/90 mmHg) Blood Pressure Control
outcome.description: Using the mean of last 5 available blood pressure measurements post randomization, we defined BP control as a means systolic BP <140 mmHg and a mean diastolic BP < 90 mmHg.
outcome.population: All randomized participants who were taking an ACEI or an ARB at the time of randomization and who had at least one post randomization BP recorded in the EMR. Missing data were not imputed.

measure.title: Percentage With Good (<140/90 mmHg) Blood Pressure Control
measure.description: Using the mean of last 5 available blood pressure measurements post randomization, we defined BP control as a means systolic BP <140 mmHg and a mean diastolic BP < 90 mmHg.
measure.population: All randomized participants who were taking an ACEI or an ARB at the time of randomization and who had at least one post randomization BP recorded in the EMR. Missing data were not imputed.
measure.units: percentage of subjects with good control

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline SBP level groups.
analysis.p_value_desc: As noted above, the a priori threshold for statistical significance for this test was .025.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications participant is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline SBP group

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR+ versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline SBP level groups.
analysis.p_value_desc: As noted above, the a priori threshold for statistical significance for this test was .025.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications participant is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline SBP group

outcome.title: Post Intervention Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Level
outcome.description: We used the latest LDL (fasting or nonfasting) available during 12 months post randomization. no missing data were imputed.
outcome.population: All randomized participants who were taking statin at the time of randomization and who had at least one post randomization LDL measurement recorded in the EMR. Missing data were not imputed.

measure.title: Post Intervention Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Level
measure.description: We used the latest LDL (fasting or nonfasting) available during 12 months post randomization. no missing data were imputed.
measure.population: All randomized participants who were taking statin at the time of randomization and who had at least one post randomization LDL measurement recorded in the EMR. Missing data were not imputed.

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline LDL subgroups.
analysis.p_value_desc: As noted above, the a priori threshold for statistical significance for this test was .025.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications participant is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline LDL group.

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR+ versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline LDL level subgroups.
analysis.p_value_desc: As noted above, the a priori threshold for statistical significance for this test was .025.
analysis.method_desc: adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications participant is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline LDL group.
analysis.estimate_desc: MeanLDL levels were sig lower for IVR+ participants than for UC participants. In subgroup analyses this difference was most pronounced in those individuals with baseline LDL levels above 100 mg/dL (adj diff=-3.6 mg/dL, 95%CI= (-5.9, -1.3), p=.002).

outcome.title: Percentage With Good (<=100mg/dL) Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Control
outcome.description: Using the last LDL measurement (fasting or nonfasting) available in the EMR post randomization, we defined good control as an LDL level <= 100 mg/dL.
outcome.population: All randomized participants who were taking a statin at the time of randomization and who had at least one post randomization LDL measurement recorded in the EMR. Missing data were not imputed.

measure.title: Percentage With Good (<=100mg/dL) Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Control
measure.description: Using the last LDL measurement (fasting or nonfasting) available in the EMR post randomization, we defined good control as an LDL level <= 100 mg/dL.
measure.population: All randomized participants who were taking a statin at the time of randomization and who had at least one post randomization LDL measurement recorded in the EMR. Missing data were not imputed.

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline LDL level subgroups.
analysis.p_value_desc: As noted above, the a priori threshold for statistical significance for this test was .025.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications participant is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline LDL group.

analysis.groups_desc: We conducted separate primary analyses of each of IVR and IVR+ versus usual care at the .025 level of significance to assure a trial-wide error rate of .05. This analysis summary is for the IVR+ versus UC comparison only. Also, we only report results here for the full sample, and not also separately for the 3 baseline LDL level subgroups.
analysis.p_value_desc: As noted above, the a priori threshold for statistical significance for this test was .025.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for site, gender, age, total number of prescription medications participant is taking, comorbid diabetes/CVD, and baseline LDL group.
analysis.estimate_desc: Though higher for the IVR+ group, LDL control did not differ significantly between the IVR+ and UC arms. Among those with poor initial control, however, control was sig better for the IVR+ arm (OR = 1.21, 95%CI = (1.04, 1.42), p=.015).

group.title: Interactive Voice Recognition (IVR)
group.description: usual care plus automated phone calls

group.title: Enhanced IVR (IVR+)
group.description: usual care plus automated phone calls plus educational mailings and mail follow-up for persistent nonadherence

event.description: specifically includes hospitalizations for liver failure or cirrhosis rhabdomyolysis as a primary discharge diagnosis
organ system categorization is incomplete. this includes hospitalization for acute renal failure, angioedema, anaphylactic shock, and anaphylactic hypotension

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

point_of_contact.organization: Kaiser Permanente Center for Health Research
